title: Objects That Remain
credits: Liesel Carter, Martin Kapel, Judith Rhodes, Trude Silman, Tom Kubie, Hari Jonkers, and Jeanne Jebson

transcript.text: Towards the end of January 1940,
I was put on a boat to come to England.
Been traveling on my own,
since I was four really, all through the war,
all through the air raids and everything.
I had a teddy bear - a Steiff,
which came with me from Germany.
But when I was in my teens,
they quote unquote ‘cousins’ decided
that I was too old for a teddy bear,
and buried it in their garden.
The only toy I brought with me from Germany.
I had favorite possessions that I couldn’t possibly take.
Some years earlier, I had been taken for a walk
by my mother. And we passed a shop
where there were some round things.
I must have been about five years,
possibly six years old.
And it was explained to me that the world is round.
And these were globes.
Giving a map of the world as it actually is.
So I wanted one.
So we went into the shop and asked how much they cost.
And that put an end to it that I wasn’t going to get one.
Some months later, one of my uncles,
he came to Leipzig on business, he stayed with us.
And of course the world imposes
certain obligations on visiting uncles.
I got my globe
and it became one of my favorite possessions
and I studied it and I knew the geography of the world.
I knew where all the principal countries were.
But of course I couldn’t possibly take it.
I got an atlas eventually, but not a globe.
I was very sorry to lose that globe.
Of course it would be out of date today.
The little suitcase that she brought on her journey is here.
And inside it I’ve got some of the things
that I know came across in 1939.
Schoolbooks - I’ve got some of them here.
I brought back any that she’d kind of written copiously in.
Because I find the most moving thing is handwriting.
The hardest thing to part with
- for me me anyway is anything with handwriting.
And I’ve got every book that my mother had her name written on.
One book that I don’t have, because I couldn’t find it.
But I know it existed at one stage
and she must have got rid of it
was one book that had the name ‘Sarah’ in
All Jewish women were forced to
add the name ‘Sarah’ to their names.
And my mother had written in one of her books:
Ursula Henrietta Barbara Sarah Michel
That’s a real piece of history and I don’t have it.
Every single object in this cupboard has a history.
This comes from Bratislava.
And she’s got a partner.
These are Slovakian.
So are these: that’s a škola or školka - ‘školka’ means ‘school’
My cousin Tony. He lives in Geneva.
Or just outside Geneva.
Has found a collection of books in the Prague Museum,
which belonged to Hugo Friedman.
And he’s in the process of trying to recover them.
And this says ‘pekár’ and that’s a ‘baker’.
The Wiener Library had a huge collection of books
that belonged to Hugo Friedman.
And these some or other have turned up
in the Prague Museum whether they are part
of the same collection -
(voices blending)
But these are my treasures.
You see, I don’t have gold.
I don’t have silver.
I was born on the eighth of September 1934.
And I was the middle of three as was by 1936.
We’ve all got very English, British sounding names.
My older brother was Robert.
I’m Thomas, and I prefer Tom, but there we go.
My younger brother, William
and he preferred being called Bill.
Whether it was something or someone out there
that said to my parents
‘You should give your children English sounding names, I don’t know.’
But they had another son who was born in 1930.
And he died 1932. And he’s buried in the Brünn, Jewish cemetery.
And his name was Michael.
So my parents gave each of their children a middle name,
beginning with the letter M.
So, Bob was Robert Milton, I’m Thomas Montague,
and Bill was William Mortimer.
So, something somewhere must have said to my parents:
You’re going to be in a different environment later on in your lives.
These are Tom’s toys, his childhood things.
When he came here in the thirties as a little boy
and actually I’ve just noticed that this is a suitcase
And it says ‘Granny’ on it, which is very sweet -
- there was a letter in this.
The letter from the palace was
because they sent a belt each to the two princesses
as a thank you for letting them come to England.
So these are part of his car and petrol stations,
Six? No. Six by the time - six or seven.
And these are the toys that we played with.
In many ways it seems like a typical - (paper rustling)
A little boy did it because
And this is a - I think like a cowboy belt? A holster.
And there is a gun and there’s a tin helmet.
I only keep everything because my parents kept everything.
She looks to have gingerish hair, but I don’t know that that’s true.
This may be an artistic impression.
But it’s my aunt Hilda and I’ve no idea what age she is.
But she looks early 20s.
Very formally dressed, going to a party.
Going for a good night out I guess.
But I only wish that the document on the back of it hadn’t faded.
And these photographs, these are all - and postcards
- all related to the Kubies.
And we’ve got hundreds and hundreds of their photographs
Pre-war Jewish lives.
So Kubies and Friedman’s.
I really liked them, because it’s just them on their holidays
and special days out. They love skiing.
They spent a lot of time in health resorts.
So yeah, they’re going all over like Hungary
and Italy and Czech Republic and -
- like a baby, and clearly a baby was born
and they took lots of photographs of them.
And then they’re just even more mundane things
with people hanging out there washing or like sitting in the car.
And with pets. Yeah, I like that this is very
‘every day’ this collection.
That’s me! Standing on a sort of balustrade
by aunt’s villa my... one of my mother’s sisters.
She was a widow and she had this wonderful villa.
You went up the steps, then there was a sort of mosaic floor.
That’s me, being taken for a walk by the Danube.
I’m wearing leggings, beautifully knitted leggings-
This actually got the history behind it.
In 1938, when the Germans went into Austria,
my father was anxious.
And so were other people, so we ended up at his mother’s
place in Vrbové.
And here we are all going for a walk
in this little country village and we’re playing silly beggars. We just chased our hats.
It’s photographs and it’s when they are - they are creased.
They’ve been folded in half and a quarter and-
- father sitting on a horse.
That’s from World War One
-is it folded up, because they had to put it discreetly
on their person? Or has it been- yeah
It was put in someone’s wallet? Perhaps in their pocket.
Or did they hide it?
Letters from father should be somewhere in here
yes that’s to do with father...
As there were three of us and we all lived in different places.
Father would write a letter - one a week
to a different one of the three of us.
And then we will then pass our letters round.
So, in the end, we all had a letter once a week.
It’s one of the last letters, because the last letter
was on my birthday. It arrived in time for my birthday.
It’s somewhere in there.
He wrote very nice letters.
He was a good dad.
I can see him in my mind’s eye sitting in this-
- one little room, with one chair and a bed
and the tiny table and teaching himself English.
He wanted - yes, he wanted to - that was his aim -
Two weeks after that he was taken away and dead.
My letter started ‘Dear Mr and Mrs Alfsen’
‘Are you the people who looked after a little,
four year old girl in 1940? 1939-1940?
If so, I’m that little girl.
And it was through my boss at the university
that I found them.
He gave me the address. And then he says:
‘Right, it’s up to you.’
And that’s when I went back into my office.
And I wrote this very, very long letter.
And then a week later, I got a letter back saying that
they were the family that looked after me,
and when am I coming?
So the next thing was to book a passage to go to Norway.
When my mother came, she went to one family
for a fortnight, and then the sort of first
and as it happened, final foster family.
She remembered being the one who had to
tell my mother that the war had started.
And this is the telegram that they received
announcing my mother’s arrival.
And she kept- I mean, she was about a hundred and-
a hundred and three when she died.
And she kept that telegram from 1939.
As we get further away from living survivors
that can actually tell us how it happened.
We are relying only on objects that remain.
But we still need a tangible link
to the individuals that owned them.
A little antiseptic powder.
A writing case in which she did actually keep all her mother’s-
- a very nice perfume bottle.
a little leather sewing - her school pencil case.
Her initials in varying sizes, large and then small.
There are two lists, one of what was destroyed on Kristallnacht.
Her signet ring and a locket with her maiden initials on,
are nowhere to be found.
I remember visiting my aunties,
my uncles,
my grandma.
And the smells.
You know they’re the most important things in my life the smells.
Certain tastes that you remember.
So that’s what I remember from my childhood.
Before - you know before things got black and nasty.
Those are the happy times.
What do you miss most?
Who did you leave behind?
How do you feel about yourself now?
Is it quiet inside?
Or do you always remember their voices?
So what do you remember most?
Everybody had to sort of turn their radios off.
You couldn’t listen to the radio anymore
and everybody had to ‘shush shush’.
If they were talking about- everybody had to whisper.
My mother pushed me under the bed.
And she started to pace
up and down past the bed.
And I was under the bed so I could see.
There was a little rug where she was pacing,
but she was pacing further.
And I started to see hair on this rug.
She was tearing her hair out.
I thought: ‘What’s happening? What’s that?’
Anyway, sooner than later, we heard big footsteps coming up
the wooden stairs, the nice apartments.
And I heard a lot of heavy wooden steps.
You know? They- they sound funny on wood.
Just not the same as on carpet or stone.
And they were heavy.
They came knocking on the door
and we didn’t answer. They knocked again, banging.
And we heard the door being broken with an axe.
You know, the lock and the doors,
just bashed in with an axe.
And French police among Gestapo came in.
A Gestapo is a special SS man.
He’s an SS man really.
He represents the man who gave the orders.
And the man who gave the orders came from the top is Hitler.
And the next one is Eichmann.
Eichmann was the man who put all his signature
to all of these arrests in Paris. Eichmann.
Who do you think of the most?
What was your favorite memory?
Do you miss her?
Do you miss him?
Do you miss them?
We had to go at night very furtively Madame Colombe and me.
And she took me to say goodbye to my grandparents
just before they were arrested.
And I said goodbye to my grandparents.
She left me there for about, I don’t know, an hour.
Because we lived, literally across the road, literally.
And I remember sort of asking - my grandfather,
he was a traditional old Polish gentleman
and he had his little hat on, his little - I call it a yarmulke.
But people call it something else.
I can’t remember the name now the English name,
but it’s a yarmulke.
And he had a very long white beard.
Long and then you know, all these hair and this white hair.
I remember snuggling into my grandfather and smelling him.
And smelling his beard.
It had - It’s really strange
because when a child has a sense of smell, it’s sharp.
It hasn’t been spoiled by anything like smoking
or the things to get in the way so you can smell
Everything. And you could - it was sort of
it wasn’t a dirty smell, he’d washed it - I just -
I can still smell him. He smelled of age and food.
What does it feel like, to be the one still alive?
And sometimes when I was younger,
I had this terrible what they call now survivor guilt.
I lived with that till I was way, way, way, way way in my 40s.
The survivor guilt. The same question that goes in your mind.
In your nightmares, day and night, day and night:
Why did they take me and leave my parents behind?
Why was I left behind?
To live a, you know, a sole life
without anybody around me that I knew.
Why, you know, had this cruel thing happened.
And I didn’t want to be, I didn’t want to be.
Because I just felt it was too cruel.
I didn’t actually understand.
I couldn’t override the fact that I was very lucky.
I couldn’t see that part.
I could only see it at a later time. But at that time,
I think the survivor guilt overrides everything else
and the happiness always is below the surface.
So all you see is layer of survivor guilt and no happiness.

title: The Children of Propaganda
credits: Martin Kapel, Val Ginsburg, and Joseph Young reading Why? Explaining the Holocaust by Peter Hayes

transcript.text: At this time in various countries,
people realised that awful things were happening in Germany
And they lobbied governments and they said:
‘We know you have a severe unemployment problem.’
Which pretty much all countries had.
‘We know you don’t want to add to it,
by bringing a lot of refugees into the country.
But will you save some of the children?’
And so in some countries, including Britain, said: yes.
And they organised what is called the Kindertransport.
‘Jews,’ said Hitler, unalterably seek to undermine
German’s fertility, military strength, and purity
in order to make them too weak to cast Jews off and out.
Thus, Jews were behind prostitution and venereal disease,
delusional notions like international law and human rights
and soft hearted ideas about the equality and brotherhood of people.
Like Nietzsche, Hitler thought Jews had introduced
the debilitating language of morality, ethics,
compassion, and empathy into the world.
Logically then, the Jew must be contained
and ultimately removed from the German sphere.
If Germany is to succeed in the struggle for living space
- Lebensraum, and survival.
Their idea of conscience was, he insisted
choosing his simile deliberately,
a blemish, like circumcision.
A supposedly unnatural alteration
of how human beings are created.
Hitler therefore promised in Mein Kampf
To rollback emancipation and drive Jews out
into their own world or abroad.
By expelling them first from German political life,
then from the nation’s cultural life, and finally,
from its economic life.
The party platform, the 25 point programme of 1920,
for instance, contained Point Four:
Calling for the denial of citizenship to Jews and their descendants
Point Five: Demanding their classification as resident aliens.
Point Six: excluding them from public office.
Point Eight: Blocking further immigration by Jews
and expelling all, who had entered the country
since the beginning of World War I.
The other atrocity took place in 1944.
And that was the so called Children’s Action.
In our ghetto, they had a number of children.
And they were our darlings. They were well looked after,
despite the hunger and the conditions.
I mean, for us, they were the symbol of our future.
We knew the Nazis are determined to exterminate
every single Jew in their power.
Orders came from Germany, that anybody
who was not employed, gainfully by work
should be eliminated.
On the 18th of March,
a detachment of SS and Ukrainian militia
marched into the ghetto, and they removed forcibly
all the children, all the disabled, all the sick people,
all the old people, anybody who couldn’t, wasn’t fit for work.
They were killed the next day.

title: Anger
credits: Val Ginsburg, Iby Knill and families

transcript.text: Val Ginsburg: Now I must point out that
whenever and wherever the Nazis occupied the country,
they made a special point of indoctrinating the population
spreading all sorts of vicious rumours
presenting the Jews as Communists, Bolsheviks,
they were presented as vermin to be exterminated.
And it seemed to work.
In fact 80% of the German killing machine
- of the Holocaust killing machine was non-German.
They knew that hunger is demoralising.
It reduces people to animal level.
And that’s what they wanted to do.
They wanted to dehumanise us, to demoralise us
and to isolate us completely from the non-Jewish population.
And then they could do away with us.
They told us to wear yellow Stars of David front and back,
to brand us as different from all the other people.
Iby Knill: I personally found that very  - I got very angry about it.
Because I couldn’t see why I should be any different to anybody else
Because none of my friends were wearing yellow stars
And I thought I would put them into an awkward situation,
if I stayed in friendships or relationships with them.
We were also taught that on public transport, we weren’t allowed to sit down.
In shops we were the last ones to be served. And I just decided
that I wasn’t going to use public transport under those circumstances.
I would rather walk to school and use a scarf to cover my yellow star.
So I seemed to spend most of my time queuing up in shops to get food
Because the rule was that people with yellow stars
should be the last ones to be served in shops.
So quite often by the time it became your turn,
there was hardly anything in the food shops nearby.
Also, our business had been what they called aryanised,
that the state took it over and put a non-Jewish person in charge
Although my parents had still to continue to work there.

title: The Song and the Painting
credits: Trude Silman and her daughter Judith Smith

transcript.text: I no longer have any reason to speak Slovak
I haven’t done so for the last 80 odd years
and the very few words in my head.
...of pageants. And I can remember standing on the little stage
in the village hall in ‘?’ with-
Sokol was this physical exercise movement.
1000s of us belonged. And the song I sang
was the song we used to sing as children
when we were going into the exercise class.
I couldn’t tell you clearly what it was. But I did sing one.
And now I can’t remember it.
Underneath Kriváň and Kriváň is one of the highest mountains in the Tatras.
If my geography still holds out. I never went to the Tatras.
And there’s a good reason for that. A) I don’t think my father
would ever afford a - a skiing holiday day for the family.
And I went to a Jewish school and every winter,
our playground was turned into an ice rink.
So we went skating and mother was a keen swimmer
and we swam in the Danube.
Before the late 1920s, the Danube used to freeze over
and people used to skate on the Danube.
And I even brought my shoes with the skates screwed in,
with me to England.
I haven’t got them anymore, because I don’t skate anymore.
It used to hang in our dining room come whatever it was,
it hung above our grand piano.
This room was between the room, which was our general room
in the flat and that general room contained-
we had a posh dining room, which also included our grand piano
with Judith hanging over the grand piano.
And we also had our cupboard cabinet,
which had our clothes in it.
And as well as that, my father had a very large desk,
with a telephone which was very unusual in those days.
And that was the desk at which he would do his writing.
And father and mother had twin beds pushed together
And the divan across the beds,
because Father used to have a nap after lunch,
because midday was when you had your main meal.
I very clearly remember the painting, because I was petrified of it.
And if I woke up and I was a bit afraid, I wanted to go in mother’s bed,
I had to go through here.
With a grand piano there and she hung up on this side of the grand piano
And she used to terrify me.
There she is. There’s Judith with a blooming head behind her skirt.
My sister and I learned piano, my brother learned violin.
Mother played the piano.
And father was very interested in opera and music.
So there was music in the house.
My brother used to make little crystal sets,
which we had a little thing,
you used to put your little pin in, and it would then make crackling noises.
And we used to listen eventually, to Mr. Hitler shouting.
And I remember that very distinctly.
Radios, I suppose were quite novel things in those days.
And father used to go into that room to listen to broadcasts.
And I can remember broadcasts of Hitler,
because he used to always shout when he was speaking.
I can’t remember the contents because I think as a young child,
it wasn’t of interest to me. We had a communal room
in which my brother sister and I slept.
We had our dining table, and father had his large desk.
And we had a telephone on the desk. So that was it.
There. The next door, we had this other in between room
where we had a grand piano and we had this fantastic painting
of Judith and Helofernes.
It used to frighten me a bit.
So I - my father was a banker -
I think most of the memory is just that it was there
above the piano. And that was all.
And that picture now hangs in my daughter’s house,
because I haven’t got room for picture, which is 4.6 ft by 4ft.
It was only after the war, when I started doing research on it,
but it was hidden during the war.
And eventually, through my eldest cousin, Igot to find out
that it had been hidden by, at my grandmother’s farm,
by some peasants or something.
And it ended up in my uncle’s house, after he had returned from Russia,
with the Czechoslovak army contingent,
which was within the Russian army at the time,
and he was a doctor, and it ended up in his house.
And then in the 1990s, after my uncle had died,
my sister and I went to where my uncle lived.
And it was called Senec. And we told his second wife
because his first wife had been murdered in Auschwitz with his daughter.
And this other lady had no idea that this painting actually belonged to
my side of the family and not to her.
So she was quite amenable for us to retrieve it.
And we brought it over to England.
My sister didn’t want to have this large painting.
But there were two other paintings two some very much smaller ones.
And she was going to have one and my brother could have had the other.
But my brother didn’t want any of things.
He didn’t want anything to do with the Holocaust anymore at that stage.
Can you see her, I can’t see her anymore?
Oh, well come up a bit further then.
Yes, let me just see if I can see her.
I can see her clearly enough.
Now I can see her better
And be able to see her better still.
Yes, I can see her now.
Hello, Judith. Haven’t seen you for a bit.
I think it was painted in the 18th century for Ludwig the II
Or Ludwig the mad or whatever he was called.
And it’s 4ft6 by 4ft.
It’s got a beautiful frame. But Judith herself has fantastic little plaits,
a beautiful gown and a bejewelled sword,
which she’s holding in her left hand and with her right hand,
Just behind her skirt, you can see the head of Holofernes.
It is sort of tastefully hidden, but obviously,
She has cut off his head and killed him.
And there she is standing, looking straight ahead of herself
When the picture came, because it’s so large,
she didn’t really have any room for it.
So she said would I like it in my house.
So I was very happy to have whatever came really,
because it’s just about the only heirloom that we’ve got.
It’s very striking. Whenever we had anyone coming into our house
for the first time, they would always notice the picture.
And we would always have a conversation about the story behind it
And where it had come from.
So it’s now in the stairwell on the third floor of our townhouse.
It was really quite difficult to get up there,
one of my sons stood on the bannister.
It’s sort of trying to manoeuvre this very heavy, large picture.
So I’ve no idea how we’ll ever get it down again, really?
I see it every day when I come up and downstairs from my bedroom.
But yes, it’s sort of part of my life, now, I suppose.
It’s you know, the one very large, concrete thing
that has come from my mother’s home.
So yes, it’s got place, close to my heart, really.
It’s the only thing really, that’s come.
And is it very coincidental that I’m called Judith?
It’s a guilt frame. And it’s plaster work.
Decorated with flowers and bunches of grapes and leaves and things
They are quite intricate, but it’s been quite damaged.
And to get it restored the frame and the picture
It would have been very expensive.
But we were also advised that actually that might
change the nature of it, so we decided that we would leave it as it is.
And I think it’s more evocative, really, that it is damaged.
I think it just shows us a lot of history to the painting,
not just about the painting when it was painted,
but the the life of the painting, that it’s travelled.
You know, hundreds of miles.
It’s been in hiding.
I think it just adds to the story of the painting.
So I like it as it is

title: Terezin
credits: Shoshanah Hoffmann, Jeanne Jebson, and Hari Jonkers

transcript.text: [Shoshanah speaking in German]
Dearest, this is the third time I’m writing directly to you
without ever having received any acknowledgement.
I can only repeat what I write in all these cards,
that I’m thinking of you with constant longing
and unchanged affection.
And that my heart has a great wish and hope
To be reunited with you one day.
...postcards that I was researching through
the Holocaust Centre in Huddersfield.
They mostly are written by Hugo Friedman,
who was a businessman in Vienna.
And some of them were written by his wife, Hildegard.
And they are to what we think was a-
She was actually a qualified nurse, Irma Doll.
And she lived in Vienna also, but we think she did some
possibly nannying work for Hugo and Hildegard.
Because they had two children.
They eventually got deported.
They all died in the Holocaust.
So, the postcards were sent to Irma Doll from Terezin.
[Shoshanah speaking in German.]
Ich umarme und küsse dich wie eh und je. Dein, Hugo.
The style of writing people have said is quite affectionate
And quite optimistic as well, which is interesting.
It doesn’t seem to contain doom and gloom.
Having said that, whilst there’s no particular evidence
of Hugo’s postcards being censored, each postcard,
from every prisoner were checked, so that there was
no overt messages in there of, you know,
what the conditions were like.
It’s interesting to see [inaudible]
the concerns they have for people.
So they’re talking very little about themselves
Other than the daily routine and
And quite often inquiring about other people that they knew
in Vienna or that other family members or...
I’ve always been curious about the typed element of communications
from concentration camps, because there is some interest
in whether there is any coding in there.
And if you look at the postcards, there are quite often
what you’d class as a typewriter errors.
So one letter comes out as bold or
slightly different to the other letters.
And there’s two or three examples of that
across different postcards.
Now, not exclusive to Hugo,
but generally across communications
from concentration camps and holding camps.
Whether there is some coded messaging in there
by putting those letters together
and obviously in their language,
seeing if there’s any sort of - [inaudible]
It seems credible, that at some point,
somebody would have tried to
communicate certain details through this,
this writing, communication.
Because I can only sort of say from my own psyche,
I think I would definitely try to put, you know,
some sort of message out there that would hint
at what was actually happening,
especially with somewhere, for instance,
like Terezin that was used as a propaganda machine.
And of course, the people in Terezin
would be aware that that was being staged.
But I think the drive to actually, well, counter that
would be too tempting for people who are
going to be able to sit down and actually think:
How can I do this? How can I get-
even if it’s just one sentence: out.
Then you know it’s got to be worth a try.
[Shoshanah reading German]
Excerpt from the Nazi propaganda film about Theresienstadt.
So the library excerpt begins with a shot outside
And there’s a signposting to the library
And then it cuts to someone entering
the glass door of the library.
We see the library desk and the staff there.
There’s a lady.
And then there’s men conversing, holding books.
It all seems very professional.
We see straight into the library with
many, many stacks of books.
There must be hundreds of them.
It all seems very professional.
And there are men reading books in the library,
conversing over books, we see, what we think,
is Hugo Friedman in a suit and bow tie.
And he sits down at a desk.
Everyone is smartly dressed in suits with jackets.
And also wearing the Star of David badges.
When they arrived at Terezin,
they were allowing us a number of suitcases,
and he’d filled his suitcase with books,
I think much to his wife’s delight, you know,
rather than provisions and clothes,
and possibly medicines and things like that.
He’d actually brought books.
The postcards were sent to
number 16 Malzgasse in Vienna.
That is actually a synagogue.
Irma Doll’s home address was Bauernmarkt 21.
Rather than sending them to her home address,
Hugo and Hildegard was sending them to a synagogue.
A 16 minute walk from Irma’s
Bauernmarkt 21 address.
One of the interesting parts of
compiling an object biography
is looking at the geography almost,
of people involved around objects.
The: is it practical
and sensible that this Irma Doll
that I’ve located at this address
would have visited these addresses?
So she would have left her house,
but where I believe her house would have stood,
there’s some billboards up at the moment
and it looks to have been some development work.
And then she would have turned right
down on to Fleischmarkt.
And then she would have turned
onto Rotenturmstraße
and she would have more or less walked then,
in a straight line across
the river there, which would have brought her
onto the other side,
where she would have continued on to Marienbrücke,
and then she would have turned left on to
Obere Donaustraße.
She would have only walked 220 metres
and then turned right on to Friedrich-Wilhelm -
She would have ended up in Leopoldgasse
which is quite a Jewish area, it was then
and I believe it still is now.
She’s heading more towards the direction
of where the Friedman’s lived -
The intended location would have been,
at this stage, the synagogue on Malzgasse.
The synagogue was destroyed
as part of the Kristallnacht
But there’s also quite near there now,
quite interestingly, there’s a
a Sigmund Freud Museum as well
So then she would have got to the Synagogue
There. Now that’s where she would have been
collecting the letters from Hugo and his family.
It became a synagogue in 1906.
It was destroyed in 1938.
And then it was used for the infirm and elderly
from 1939 until 1942.
Because that might be Irma’s association
with this particular building,
other than the Jewish synagogue.
Because she was a nurse.
In June of 1942, it became one of the four
Jewish assembly points in Vienna,
in preparation for their deportation.
So that whole journey would have taken
about 16 minutes from her home,
across to the synagogue.
She could then continue on to the Friedmann’s house,
Obviously, when they were still resident there
before they were deported.
This this journey was particularly interesting to me,
because I wanted to be reassured
that I was looking at the right person.
To me to actually do at this stage
a Street View walk from Irma Doll’s home address
to the synagogue, and then a little bit further
to Hugo’s house in Vienna is quite fascinating.
Because I’m seeing what they saw,
to some extent I know the landscapes
and buildings have changed.
But not so drastically that you can’t be actually stood
on the same pavement or leant against the same wall
or looking at the same windows,
you know, touching the same door.

title: Wires and Fences
credits: Ibi Ginsburg, John Chillag, Eugene Black, Arek Hersh and families; and the USC Shoah Foundation

transcript.text: And as walked,
oh we walked probably a mile or so
we passed on our right hand side
these huge big camps
and they were surrounded by barbed wire.
But real big, efficient wires.
And between the two wires,
there was a huge, big ditch.
And the outside wire was electrified.
And there was a constant humming from it.
That power was so strong,
that you could smell it.
It had a scorching smell
and every so often,
there were lookout towers where an SS was standing
with guards, with a machine gun.
Just in case somebody goes to the wire,
because if you went near that wire,
half a yard
you were just sucked in
- you were electrocuted.
Each of these sort of ‘better’ groups were sort of
identifiable in one way or another.
There was a gypsy camp
and a Czech camp and so on.
Dogs in between and watch towers
with machine guns trained on us
so there wasn’t really any escape from there.
If the guard (?) didn’t get you, the dogs did,
if the dogs didn’t - then the watch tower.
A number of people had, so to say, escaped.
They walked straight into the electric barbed wire.
It was an escape
- of suicide.
And some people had done that.
And a horrible smell was all over the camp
- terrible.
The time I spent in Ausschwitz and Birkenau
That was there, continuously,
24 hours a day.
The other people, around 150 of them,stood outside.
The two SS men still stood in front of the gate.
And as I walked in the church I- my thoughts were:
Elderly people, children, and so on.
The omen was not very good,
because I’ve seen what Germans do with people like that.
And then I thought to myself, whatever happens
to my mother and brother and sister, I’m with a family.
And it was very traumatic for me
Because I didn’t want to be parted from
my mother and my brothers and sisters
And then we were marched off
and that’s the last time I’d see-
my mother and brothers and sister.
They decided to liquidate the Ghetto.
They told us to assemble in the square
and they marched us to the church.
It was a fairly small church and they pushed in
4000 people at that church, without water,
without any food, without any toilet facilities.
Imagine 4000 People in a place
without any toilet facilities.
They told us to come out from the church
and there were two SS officers
And they look you over and asked you your profession.
I told them I was a tailor.
I couldn’t thread a needle,
but I thought: You know, if I can do something,
They’ll take me.
They told me to go with my mother,
and our family, back into the church.
Anyway, it was a very hot day,
I wanted to go for some water, to the gate.
And when I did, the SS men shouted at me, the officer:
‘What’s your profession?’
I told him, I was a tailor, once again, a tailor.
He told me to run now, join the 150 people.
And we were taken to Lodz Ghetto.
And all the 3000 - how many? - were taking to Chelmno.
And they were gassed.
And then burried in mass graves.

title: Constant Vigilance
credits: Heinz Skyte and family, Kath Shackleton from Fettle Animation, and the BBC

transcript.text: Well, you know, you’re a survivor, because you are there.
Well, obviously my contemporaries
who committed these atrocities are dreadful
but I’m concerned that sometimes I think
what I would have been, if I hadn’t been Jewish.
Would I have been a Nazi?
And I probably would.
You know, it’s very difficult for a 12, 13, 14 year old
to resist the temptations
the Nazis offered for kids of that age.
Uniforms, camp fires,
learning to shoot rifles,
things like that, as they did in the Hitler Youth.
And it’s very, very difficult for a kid of that age
to resist that temptation
and not be part of the crowd.
It’s a warning I suppose to people to be vigilant,
not to be bystanders,
but to speak out if they encounter bad things
or evil things.
This is exactly what’s happened:
The Germans stood by and did nothing
So that is the warning:
and sometimes enthusiastic supporters of Hitler.
Constant vigilance.
Constant vigilance.

title: Black Milk
credits: Avery Rain Knill, Christopher Knill, Tansy Spinks (violin) & Phil Hardman at Northern Audio Productions

transcript.text: I had a mother who when up when I was born.
She had just, you know, escaped from undescribable trauma,
lived in the face of death and the dying.
It’s unimaginable, what she was really exposed to.
I’m sure, in her books and in her writings and in her lectures,
she’s not, I don’t think she’s even scraped the surface,
or dared to scrape the surface,
or been able to scrape the surface
of what she really had to endure.
Well, when I was younger, when I was a child,
she taught me how to spin the wool,
this fresh wall from from farmers in like, Scotland or something
we would sit together in the living room,
and she teach me how to, like, clean the wool and prepare it
and spin it, and then show me stuff she was making with it.
She made, like, cardigans.
I think she made a cardigan for me at some point
that I had when I was little,
because I still knit and crochet and stuff all the time.
And I always think of her when I do that.
We know psychologically that if you allow that degree of trauma
to go under the you know, to penetrate,
you die, you don’t survive.
And so some way you have to protect you have to lock it out.
I’m a psychologist, and I work with these- It’s not surprising
that I work with these kind of things for myself.
It’s interesting. I can’t remember the statistic,
75 or 80% of second generation survivors
work in the health services as psychologists or doctors or therapists,
you know, and and why is that? It’s interesting, isn’t it?
And that’s been my salvation really,
understanding it myself as a phenomenon,
and this enabled me to a large extent,
to in a way, heal.
Heal, yeah.
I read some parts of the first book, but for me, honestly,
the way the transgenerational trauma works for me is
I get quite uncomfortable reading about
anything that has to do with war in general,
t’s like I get a trauma response that it’s not from my own life,
in response to any sort of stories about things like that,
or her story, like, I can’t physically like process it.
All the survivor wants to do is to protect their kids,
of course, but you can’t do that.
You know, you think you can do that,
but you can’t do that.
And they do it either by coming extremely devout,
loyal to the Jewish faith, or rejecting it completely,
pretending it wasn’t there,
and kind of that’s what my mother did
for a large part of her life.
When I get into this, it moves-
my feelings get very sort of,
it opens up something very powerful in me,
because it’s been such a emotionally powerful journey.
She thought she protected me.
She thought that I was free, that it hasn’t been transferred,
you know, but it’s really been a huge
piece of work for me for 20 years or so, and is continuing in a way.
She talked about it later in her life, obviously, about
what she’d been through when she wrote her books and everything.
But she’s very she was very emotionally detached from it,
which I think is something she had to do to cope with the trauma.
Obviously, I can’t imagine.
So I never talked to her personally about it.
When you grew up as a young child or as a baby
with someone that has just, in a way, escaped or
come out of multiple traumas over several years,
you’re going to be living with someone who
has very explicit post traumatic stress symptoms,
which you know at that time nobody knew anything about it,
but it means you know emotional distance,
not being in contact with your feelings,
not being able to have empathy,
not because you’re not empathetic,
but because you know your traumas are so severe
that you have enough surviving and managing from day to day.
day to day. And you just imagine everything we know today
about child development, the important emotional presence,
the importance of emotional presence,
what that will do to that child, in terms of feeling, you know,
not seen or understood, or feeling lonely or fearful.
There’s something very dangerous out there.
You know, there’s nowhere to go.
There’s no haven, there’s no safe haven, secure base.
Yeah. There’s a French poet, Paul Celan.
He wrote, he was a Holocaust survivor himself.
And he talked about, he intuitively understood these things
when he wrote a poem called Black Milk.
Black breast milk and it passes something on
but what is passed on, the child has nothing to hang it on to.
There’s no hooks to hang there to understand it.
But I’m very, very fortunate that being able to
use my life to understand these things and help other people.
I bear no resentment, no bitterness, no-
just I feel just love, and I did for the last few years with my mother.
But it could easily be- I’ve experienced many of my clients
who are very glad when their parents die.
They just have never felt understood or met.
Because our parents, they can’t never understand us,
because, if they understand us, they have to understand themselves
and open up for spaces within themselves
which are just so threatening to access.
You can’t go there and and that’s very understandable,
Very understandable.
That these books and everything she wrote was all part and parcel.
This need to show that she was worth,
worthy of being in the world.
Having to prove her worth all the time in one way or another.
And that’s a very strong, strong driving force for her,
as you’re the evidence of the fact that life goes on,
that the Nazis didn’t succeed, right?
I ended up in the evidence side,
and I have to shine and go out there.
That’s the that’s the absolute message you’re getting
as a child of a second generation.
You get out there and shine and show the world
that Hitler didn’t succeed.
What gives me meaning and a feeling of relevance
is to be there for others. And I don’t mean that I wasn’t,
I was also so for my mother, but as a therapist, I am really using
this knowledge that I’m sharing in therapy room,
and I really can see and witness the extent to which this really
can support and help people understand themselves
and heal themselves, because it gives me a perspective very,
very few people have on life, and I’m very, very grateful for that,
because It’s so rewarding to be allowed to do that.
She’s very- she was very brave.
She’s like she’s the most powerful woman I think I ever met in my life,
because she went through so much, and she persisted through it,
and she pushed even farther and achieved so many things.
To me, she’s just like a symbol of like:
Don’t give up, just keep pushing forward and do your best.
And she went far. She got places.
That’s the only way I can sum it up, I think.
So maybe that’s the point of my life.
Maybe that’s why I am who I am, doing what I do.
Is that I’m going to somehow or another
- without having two big ideas about myself -
But, you know, I’m in a position to be able to try to,
in a way, resolve, to a certain extent, family traumas.
But to be able to embrace your life
and honour your life whilst you’re still alive.
I think that’s such an important thing to be able to do,
for better or for worse.
And forgive yourself, yeah.
It takes a lot of courage to take on, you know,
the consequences of your actions.
For better or for worse, you know?
And, yeah, you know, she’s taught me a lot
and I’m deeply grateful for this.
I’m deeply grateful for having had the mother I had,
and having to have her work through these things,
because when I my whole ability and capacity
as a therapist is dependent on that understanding
that I’ve been forced to embrace.
Which is incredibly challenging to acquire.
I think it’s quite phenomenal attitude, because I, you know,
I could have taken my own life when I was 45 grand about there.
I could, I could have just ended it all, because
the whole thing seemed so insurmountable
Since I was little, since I was born,
I’ve been a very strong willed person.
And I think that definitely comes from her,
because we’re we’re very similar in many ways,
so very different in very many other ways.
But the thing that I saw in her, a lot, that I also saw myself,
was that it’s almost like stubbornness, but it’s in a good way.
It’s like, instead of being stubborn and annoying,
it’s more just like, stubborn in the way that I refuse to give up
on things, like I refuse to just fall down and then give up.
Because I’ve been through a lot of ups and downs in my life,
and there’s many points that if I wasn’t the strong willed person that I am,
I would have given up and I wouldn’t be here.
And I think that’s really something that she gave to me.
My main focus of attention right now is my own death.
I’m working with embracing my own mortality and-
but just to be able to embrace death as something
that I can embrace with gratitude as a natural
and normal conclusion of a life that’s lived to the full.
Right? It’s what I would have wished for my mother.
So maybe, if I can do that, I can somehow, in a way, heal her.
Yeah, in a way, within me, we carry our parents within us.
You know, certainly.
Hier wohnte -
Hier wohnte -
- deportiert.
- deportiert.
- ermordert.
They’re made out of brass and
they they always start off with:
‘Hier wohnte’
‘Hier lebte’
or sometimes ‘hier arbeitete’
‘here worked’ and then,
the name of the person, their year of birth.
And after that as much information as is known
about their eventual fate.
Sometimes there is a notation
that the person committed suicide
and they’re kind of quite affecting
the way it’s phrased sometimes it’s sort of:
‘Selbstmord’, but I read one that said:
‘Fled into death.’
It’s an another way to learn history.
It’s an open book and you’re reading:
They killed 6 million Jews.
That’s abstract.
But when the students just around the corner,
in their neighbourhood,
they can imagine and that idea they can read:
‘Paul, he was so old as me.’
When he was deported.
I think that’s another way to learn history.
In the old part of Cologne, the South part,
old women came and said to me:
Well, it’s pretty good what you’re doing here
But here in our area, never lived gypsy people
and she really don’t know.
And it was ther same with the Jewish population.
They were totally, well, neighbours
And that was at least idea to bring back some names in front of the houses where it started
where other people were at their home
and then were called out
and were deported.
And bring back the names, that was -
Then I had a contact to the rabbi of Cologne
and he told me, I don’t know where it is in the Talmud.
But a man is forgotten when his name is forgotten.
That was idea to bring back the names.
Alfred Levy, Jahrgang 1881. Deportiert 1940 Gürs. 1942 - Ermordet.
They were cousins.
One of my great grandmother.
Older members of my family.
They were old men at the time,
who lived in a small town
on the Southern German Weinstraße,
and they were very, very much loved
members of the community
and very sadly missed when they were deported.
And there are still a handful of people alive today
who were children in the 1930s
who have very, very fond memories of these two old men.
...von Alfred Levy and seinem Bruder Gustav.
erzählte die heute 84-Jährige.
Oft machte sie einen Abstecher zur Wohnung der Levys,
Alfred, the younger brother by 10 years,
was very well known in Klingenmünster, their hometown.
He worked as a travelling salesman of
farming and domestic equipment.
and also ran a shop.
The brothers lived together.
They had a housekeeper
until it was forbidden by law
for Gentiles to work for Jewish families.
And then she had to stop looking after them.
He was very, very popular.
The children absolutely loved him.
He allowed them to run riot in their house,
play games with them,
fed them sweets and biscuits,
allowed them to ride on his horse.
They were much more innocent times.
Tripping the memory, or tripping the thoughts.
Sometimes people asked me:
‘You can make it in the Fabrik, by machine.’
But then I say:
‘Auschwitz was a fabric - for death.’
So, every stone is made by hand, individually.
I think it’s very important.
When I started, for me as an artist,
it was conceptual art.
In the way, I’d never had the idea to realise.
But what then a priest in Cologne,
a Protestant priest, who told me:
‘Well Gunter, you will never reach the million,
but you can start small.’
Well now, it’s I think, next year to go to:
100,000 stones. In 29 countries in Europe.
Maybe 30 countries.
And that’s idea:
to bring the stones to every country in Europe
where the Deutsche Wehrmacht, the SS, the Gestapo
deported people, killed people and with terror.
That there as a symbol, be these stones.
And that will go on and on.
And for this I made a foundation,
that it can go on, because well I’m born in ‘47, so.
But I think it will. It is for the future.
And especially young people are really, very interested.
How could this happened in the so called
Land der Dichter und Denker. Germany.
And at least, never have it happen again.
Hier wohnte -
Hier wohnte -
Deportiert.
Deportiert.
Ermordert.

title: Thin Line
credits: Jenny Kagan & Phil Hardman at Northern Audio Productions

transcript.text: It was just layers of information that arrived
seemingly effortlessly.
When I was very little, she told me funny little tales about the watchman’s dog
or about what- how they had to cope with going to the toilet when they were in hiding.
And they didn’t actually talk about
the much more difficult elements of the story until later,
but they were drip fed and bed,
and because they spoke about it among themselves a lot.
It also wasn’t about me being told it was just about listening
to the talk around the table,
because they spoke about it all the time,
which is very rare in survivors’ families.
In a way, it was the most exciting thing that ever happened to them.
And so it was such a huge thing in their life
They talked about the biggest thing that my mom was 17,
such a formative experience.
and it was - it formulated the way they saw the world -
It defined them as people in different ways.
It was always the underpinning- narrative
of everything that happened, subsequently.
They always said that they saw not only the worst of humanity,
but also the best of humanity.
The fact that they were saved.
They were saved by the people that supported them.
A life affirming experience in the midst of all this horror,
which is crazy,
but there was that real balance of extremes that made it
a really vital background, you know,
and you’ve got that absolute extremes of horror
and extremes of somebody who is prepared to risk-
as my mother always would say,
not only his life, but the life of this entire family.
I needed a project and I just I said to my Mum:
Why don’t we draw the box?
Because she’d always talked about the box.
They both always talked about the box.
And when I was little, I had a very clear idea of the box,
because she would describe it to me, and she would say,
my me and your father would lie this way,
and your grandma would lie this way.
We could only come out at night.
And I had a toy box in my room,
so in my head, that was this. That was the box.
The lid would open at night.
And I think there was probably a kids program
where toys came out of a box at night.
That was my image of the box for many, many years.
And I was in my 20s, when I went to Amsterdam for the first time,
went to the Anne Frank House.
Oh, my God, this is what hiding place is like.
How ridiculous. All those years I’ve been thinking of this box
We started to talk about and I said: Why don’t we draw it?
So I started to do little sketches,
and she’d look at them and go:  ‘I don’t know’
You know, it’s a piece of paper, it was an object.
So then I started to make little models years in theater.
So I started sticking things together and balsa wood models,
and I’d bring them to Huddersfield to show her,
and she’d go ‘a bit smaller that way’, or ‘the bed was a bit higher’,
and I’d go and remake it.
She still go ‘No, I don’t know.’ And then eventually I said:
‘Well, look, why don’t- it’s only, you know, it’s only six foot square.
Why don’t I make a rough layout of it?
So I got some two by one,
and I screwed it together into a rough frame,
and I covered it with paper. I said, come and have a look.
She walked into this space, and she looked at it and said:
‘Oh, the door’s on the wrong side.’
You’ve seen 25 drawings and five models.
How come you’re only just realizing?
It was real learning moment of
actuallythe real thing is completely different.
And although I can work in drawings and I can think in models,
not everyone can. So I built the real thing to scale.
I showed it as my end of year piece.
And she came to the opening, and she said: It’s very good.
She said, ‘but still a little bit t oo big’,
because my head, you know, you just, you go,
it must have been. And then she said, Five foot, five,
took six inches off it. Rebuilt it, installed it in the museum,
and she came and looked at it, and she said: Now it’s perfect.
I remembered the ‘Night of the Ghetto’
the book that my dad had written.
And went back to that and thought
What did he write about the hiding place?
And how it was situated?
And so I went and read his description,
astonished to find that his dimensions were different.
They were smaller still.
So that was sort of the start of it
was that notion that memory was not fixed.
So I then built his version of the box,
her version of the box,
and my imagined version of the box
For her the most difficult thing
and the thing that she never really dealt with, actually, I think
the one thing that was profoundly difficult was her father’s death.
When they came out of the ghetto,
she wasn’t sure if she wanted to leave England,
because her little brother- leave for England
because her little brother was in Kaunas
But the one deciding factor was that she said
she would have found it very difficult to stay in Lithuania
and to walk down the streets and to never know
if the man she was passing was the man
that had beaten her father to death.
He was arrested the day after the German invasion,
and he was beaten to death, along with 50 to 60 other Jews
by Lithuanians with clubs in the yard of a garage
on the Wednesday two days later.
And she didn’t find out about it till after the war,
and then in the 50s, a German newspaper published photographs
of the event, because there’d been Wehrmacht officers present
who had taken photographs,
and these photographs were printed in a German newspaper.
And she got copies of those photographs,
and she put them in the back of the family album.
She was obsessed by photographs.
She had albums upon albums of photographs,
and in one of those albums, on the back two pages
were these two photographs of groups of men
having been clubbed to death
and the man standing over them still with the clubs.
And they were in our family albums.
I’d always known they were there,
so I grew up seeing them in the back of the albums.
When I was doing history at school,
we were asked to bring in something from home about the war.
So I snuck into my mum’s bedroom and I took
from the back of the photo album these two photographs
without telling her. And the reason I didn’t tell her was not
for a moment that I thought she would mind me taking them.
It was because I was terrified that I knew be in such trouble
that I had left it till the morning of the lesson to do my homework,
so I didn’t dare tell her, and if I’d asked her,
maybe we would have had a discussion about how to navigate it.
But we didn’t. I just grabbed them and went to school.
And because I’d seen them all my life,
and because I’d known this story all my life,
I had no idea the impact of it.
And everybody else had brought in, you know,
I think somebody might have brought in a medal,
and somebody might have brought in a box of matches,
and I brought in a couple of photographs
of my grandfather being clubbed to death,
which was quite a, quite an extraordinary thing to do on reflection.
But I did it very casually, and I think my history teacher loved me.
I think it was the best history lesson she ever gave,
and she didn’t have to do anything.
How do you tell stories that are accessible and engaging
about something that’s so terrible?
I was born on the 28th of October,
which is the anniversary of what was called
the big action in the Kaunas ghetto.
The ghetto was closed at the end of August,
and on the 28th of October,
a decree was issued well prior to the 28th of October,
that all the inhabitants of the ghetto that
at that time were just short of 30,000
should gather in the square of the Democrats at 6am.
Anyone remaining in their houses was going to be killed.
Going to be killed, so that everyone had to go.
And the ghetto was divided into two.
People were sent to the left or to the right,
and those sent to the left were murdered that that next day,
and that was just short of 10,000
So this was such a huge event in everyone’s experience at the ghetto.
You speak to any survivor of the Kaunas ghetto,
and they will talk in almost the same language about that day.
It’s extraordinary.
So for my mum, it was really important that I was born on that day.
Because it meant that something good happened on a day
that something so terrible had happened.
For me, that’s, that’s one of the most important things
about that heritage that I have
is that sense of how close that line is,
between survival and death,
between success and fate.
You know, all those lines, how thin lines are generally.
And I think that’s something that
I feel privileged to have grown up with,
because it makes life more when death is so close.
You know, I don’t just want to share the horrors of this story.
I want to share what my parents took from it, which is
how it can feed us,
and how we can gain and grow
and take something from them,
It’s vital, because we’re going to stop horrible things happening,
but we might be able to learn how to navigate them.

title: Enosh
credits: Rudi Leavor and family, and Stephen Muir

transcript.text: Enosh
When people gradually started to learn that I was researching Jewish music
A lot of people said: ‘Oh, you must speak to Rudi Leavor.’
When I first met Rudi, which was at the Bradford synagogue,
I asked him what his story was, as it were.
He talked about his youth, and then the Nazi occupation, etc.
And how he’d come to England. And he talked a little bit about
how he’d been a singer in the synagogue, most of his life,
eventually became the Kantor the Bradford synagogue.
He played violin, as a child,
but had never had any kind of formal theoretical,
university level type of education in music.
In fact, he was a dentist, very good dentist, I believe.
But he kept that music going. And then in the nine- in the 70s,
He composed Enosh.
Not- I don’t know if it was exactly out of the blue,
but it seems to be out of the blue.
He told me about this in a very matter of fact, way.
‘Oh, yeah. And then in the 70s I,’
‘I composed this opera’ as he called it.
Not quite accurate, but that doesn’t matter.
I composed his opera called Enosh.
I said: ‘Oh yeah, what’s that?’
And he said: ‘Oh it’s a it’s a thing for chorus and full orchestra solos.
[inaudible]
Rudy was very musically knowledgeable,
from a sort of very advanced amateur level.
He knew his opera very well.
He was an admirer of Bach, and Mozart, Beethoven,
you know the sorts of classic-
My father played the piano, Chopin, Schubert, Beethoven,
and my mother sang
As a child or his father had some LPs, I think,
that they listened to, I think one of them was
the Berlioz L’enfance du Christ,
which remained a very dear piece to him throughout his life
and was performed in the same concept as-
well an extract from it was was performed in same concert as Enosh.
And so, he was steeped in a sort of Western classical music tradition,
as well as a synagogue music tradition,
some of which is very similar to that western classical tradition,
but some of it some of which is not.
And it’s very almost Islamic in nature, or Arabic, certainly, in its influences.
And so what I think he was trying to achieve was to meld
his knowledge of classical music with that synagogue tradition.
Enosh
It’s like an oratoria, really.
Rudi, didn’t just leave the tunes as they were.
He sort of intervened musically, he changed aspects of some of the
what we might call hymns, in the synagogue.
The classic one is Enosh ‘Mankind’
which is sung on Yom Kippur. It’s very serious.
It’s sort of the end of a long process of
praying and singing towards the end of a fast.
It’s very well known in the Jewish world.
But he changed aspects of harmony,
sort of played around with the rhythm a little bit.
You’ll hear it start and you’ll think ‘Oh, yes that’s Enosh.’
And then you’ll hear something a bit different.
And you’ll think ‘Oh, that’s not quite what I remember.’
And it makes you think more about the music
rather than just hearing a familiar tune.
What he was trying to do is to is to sort of feed into a tradition,
or two traditions, the Jewish and the Western classical music.
But to disrupt it a little bit and draw our attention to certain things.
And the soloists music is in a much more modern idiom.
It’s beautifully written actually.
The story is of the Jewish people, essentially.
It starts with the people of Israel, being happy
to have arrived in the Promised Land.
And then it becomes gradually more serious
as they’re overtaken by various events throughout history.
Whilst it’s never upfront, explicitly expressed,
you can identify particular historical things,
and eventually coming to the Holocaust.
And there’s a moment where there’s obvious references to Hitler
without naming him and to the horrors that
were perpetrated upon the Jewish people.
And then after that, there is a short epilogue, I guess
whereby there is a sort of sign of hope for the future,
I would say a qualified hope, not a
not an a sort of an ecstatic, uncontrolled hope.
But there is a sort of root space for reflection and optimism.
He left Germany quite early on in his childhood.
And he left before the worst of the atrocities otherwise,
one might assume, sadly, that he wouldn’t have survived.
So thank God, he did leave.
So he never spoke to me about that individually,
but I knew the history, more or less.
We went by train, ship, train, and then train.
I liked travelling, the excitement,
I think, whilst again, he never articulated it precisely.
I think that that was quite a powerful
personal, I wouldn’t say reconciliation with,
but engagement with an expression of that trauma that survivors suffer.
I think certainly the power of the music that he wrote,
that comes from somewhere.
I think he was working through a number
of historical, emotional aspects
From Hamburg to Bremer Hafen we had the compartment to ourselves.
Then the customs officer came around,
he asked my father to go to another compartment.
We stopped at a station. When we set off I said:
‘Where’s daddy?’
My mother was just as frightened. But she said: ‘He’ll be along.’
They had asked him questions and body searched him.
He did talk about his, his escape,
for want of a better word, the music and the narrative in the text
works through some of that idea of escape,
and finding a better life somewhere.
And then, the risk of it all happening again,
and eventual partial catharsis.
So there was a tender to take us on the ship to the quay side.
We went to the station. It seemed very dark.
It was November. So it got dark early.
It was raining, there were gas lights,
and the train puffed a lot of steam.
That was our entry to England.
And the new and better life.
One could tell when he felt something very deeply.
He’s very sincere man. A very gentle man.
I would say. One of my main impulses behind doing it was
Yes, there’s a self interest in terms of the research
and the potential academic outcomes and things like that.
But actually, the most important thing for me was to do it,
to get it done for Rudi.
Because he kept saying to me, I’m on a limited timescale here.
He knew that he wouldn’t be surviving another 20 years or something
and that it needed to be done there and then.
And so, within the kind of confines of what I could do,
I wanted to do it for him primarily.
